Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Montane Avian Elevational Range Shifts and Land Use Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although biogeographers and conservation biologists know that deforestation, responsible for 95% of the world's endangered species, is a serious threat to species conservation, the impacts of this land use change is still ignored in terms of its effects on the elevational ranges of species. Preliminary observations suggest that lowland deforestation affects the ranges of species in the forest above when compared to forests with intact lowlands. Understanding the distribution of species along natural and altered altitudinal gradients is important for the design of current conservation strategies, and could be instrumental in predicting future distributions of species in the face of climate change. The biologically richest hotspot is the northern Andes of South America. Colombia has more bird species than any other country - approximately 1900 - and a rate of discovery of one new bird species per year. Within Colombia, the highest concentrations of endemic and small-range birds are in the Western Andes, peaking at 46 species. The diversity of non-endemic birds, and other taxa, is also exceptional. The western slope of the Western Andes is mostly covered by intact forest, but the eastern slope has suffered severe deforestation due to road access and human settlement. To achieve the goals of understanding elevational range changes, the investigators will sample three pairs of altitudinal transects (2000-2900m) in which one will be completely covered by mature forest, while the other will lack forest in the lowlands. In the Mesenia-Paramillo Reserve in the northern part of the Western Andes, the project will describe species richness and the variation of abundance for each species along these transects. Employing observations and mist-netting, and aided by a team of local staff and biologists-in-training, the investigators will identify the effects of lowland deforestation on species ranges using statistical models. Expected results from this project include current bird distribution information and 3D maps, and the establishment of permanent banding stations along the altitudinal transects which will be sampled periodically after this project concludes. These results will inform a global understanding of how deforestation and climate change affects species and so aid those who manage them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deforestation is one of the main causes of species endangerment and extinction in the tropics. From previous studies, we know that deforestation causes habitat loss, and fragmentation, leaving small patches of forests that are isolated and not as effective at protecting species. Yet we still ignore how deforestation impacts the way that species occupy mountains. Perhaps it is beneficial to have long portions of forest along the mountain slope, and maybe losing some of that forest will affect the individuals higher up the mountain? 

We set out to answer these questions in the Western Andes of Colombia, one of the most biodiverse places on Earth. Here, we monitored birds and how they distribute themselves along mountains. Some of the areas we studied were covered by forest completely, while other areas lacked forest at the bottom part of the mountain. We wanted to understand how that lack of forest would impact the birds in the remaining forest. We set up bird monitoring stations along the mountains, at different elevations, and surveyed the bird community using observations and captures with mist-nets. All birds were identified and counted, the captured birds were banded and released. 

By comparing mountains with different amounts of forest, we were able to assess the impact of deforestation on these birds' elevational ranges (their distributions along the mountain). We found that the lack of forest did not affect how high birds are in the mountain, or how abundant they are at different elevations. However, it did have a significant effect on how wide their elevational range was. For instance, if the same species was found on both types of mountains, it would be found along a larger area in the mountain completely covered by forest, while its range would be reduced in the mountains that lacked forest. This species then, would span 400m on mountains with forest, and only 200m in those partially deforested.

This finding is very important in understanding conservation from a different perspective. We need to protect forests that cover a wider array of elevations, instead of having forest at the same elevation everywhere. As climate change continues to warm our planer, species are going to need a variety of habitats to move into, and they will likely move up mountains. Corridors of connected forests in mountains will be fundamental to the survival of biodiversity. This threat from climate change will be additional to that from deforestation, so conservationists need to plan accordingly.

Through this research project, and specifically during its long field season, twenty local people were trained in bird monitoring techniques. Some of these people live near this protected area, and some were from the nearest town, but none had ever been exposed to scientific methodologies, or birds. We were able to hire them as field assistants and train them in bird banding and point count techniques. After our field season ended, some of them have been hired by other researchers as field assistants thanks to the skills they acquired during this project. This job is a great alternative to their former jobs as cooks, construction assistants, and trail maintenance staff.

Our research project had significant scientific results that will inform conservation decisions, and it has also had an impact on local communities by providing training and contributing to their understanding of natural ecosystems.
